Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Standard and Long Intramedullary Hip Nails for Reverse Obliquity Fractures

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were patients aged 67-95 years with reverse obliquity fractures of the proximal femur.

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients aged 67-95 years with reverse obliquity fractures of the proximal femur.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised to receive either standard or long (≥34 cm) intramedullary hip nails.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was reoperation rate due to fixation failure, assessed over a minimum follow-up of 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to patients or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Thirty-three patients were randomised: 15 to standard nails and 18 to long nails.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Reoperation rates showed no significant difference between groups.

Harms.evidence: Two patients in the long-nail group required revision surgery due to implant failure and deep infection.
